title: 106_hr1625
content: The Act may be cited as the "Human Rights Information Act". Congress finds that the national and international protection of human rights is a key value of democracy, with federal agencies holding documents on human rights violations abroad. Requests for legal assistance on human rights violations are expected, including declassification of documents for investigations and prosecutions. The United States receives requests from foreign authorities for legal assistance on human rights violations, including declassification of documents. A Spanish court magistrate recently requested information on General Augusto Pinochet. Strengthening declassification procedures is crucial for protecting and promoting human rights globally. The expedient declassification of human rights documents in compliance with the Freedom of Information Act will protect global human rights by strengthening the rule of law internationally and holding Federal agencies accountable. The United States is committed to promoting human rights and democracy worldwide through diplomatic, economic, and military efforts, as well as support from NGOs and citizens. The United States plays a leadership role in promoting human rights and democracy globally. It is crucial for newly established democratic societies to investigate and prosecute human rights violations to prevent the need for renewed US engagements. The US has long provided international leadership in ending impunity for human rights violations and promoting the rule of law worldwide. The United States has played a key role in promoting human rights globally by supporting international investigations and tribunals for gross human rights violations. The US has ratified the Convention against Torture and should provide assistance in criminal proceedings related to torture. The United States should provide evidence for proceedings related to torture and adopt measures for free access to information in investigations of human rights violations. The Guatemalan peace accords, supported by the US, included an investigation on human rights violations. The United States strongly supports an investigation by the Clarification Commission on human rights violations in Guatemala. Despite the investigation's conclusion, many questions remain unanswered, including the whereabouts of the disappeared. The Commission recommended utilizing all resources to clarify these issues. Two days after presenting a parallel investigation, Bishop Juan Jose Gerardi, director of the Historical Memory Recovery Project, was assassinated. The director of the Historical Memory Recovery Project in Guatemala, Bishop Juan Jose Gerardi, was assassinated two days after presenting a parallel investigation. President Clinton acknowledged US support for military forces involved in repression in Guatemala and emphasized the need to support peace and reconciliation. The National Commissioner for Human Rights in Honduras has been requesting US documentation on human rights violations since 1993. The National Commissioner for Human Rights in Honduras has been requesting US documentation on human rights violations since 1993, with some aspects still pending. SEC. 3. DEFINITIONS. This Act defines key terms such as "human rights record," "agency," and "gross violations of internationally recognized human rights." The term "human rights record" refers to information on gross violations of human rights post-1944 held by the US Government. "Agency" includes various government entities involved in foreign policy and intelligence. "Gross violations of internationally recognized human rights" is defined as per the Foreign Assistance Act of 1961. SEC. 4 of the Act governs the declassification and public disclosure of human rights records regarding Guatemala and Honduras post-1944. Agencies must identify, review, and organize these records for public release within 30 days of completion. The President must report to Congress on agency compliance within 150 days. An agency can delay public disclosure of a human rights record if it poses a serious threat to national security, such as revealing intelligence agents or sources currently in use by the United States Government. The public disclosure of a human rights record can be delayed if it would interfere with intelligence activities, impair national security, reveal confidential sources, invade personal privacy, or pose a risk of harm to individuals. The public disclosure of a human rights record can be delayed if it poses a risk of harm to individuals, constitutes an unwarranted invasion of personal privacy, or compromises confidential relationships requiring protection. It shall not be grounds for postponement that an individual named in the record was an intelligence asset, with the term "intelligence asset" defined as a covert agent. The human rights record can be delayed if it risks harm, invades privacy, or compromises confidential relationships. The term "intelligence asset" refers to a covert agent as defined in the National Security Act of 1947. SEC. 6. REQUEST FOR HUMAN RIGHTS RECORDS FROM OFFICIAL ENTITIES IN OTHER COUNTRIES. If a US agency receives a request for human rights records from certain international entities or countries investigating violations, they must review and disclose the records. SEC. 7. REVIEW OF DECISIONS TO WITHHOLD RECORDS. The Appeals Panel reviews agency determinations to postpone public disclosure of human rights records. They direct disclosure unless there is clear evidence that the record is not a human rights record or qualifies for postponement. If they agree to postpone disclosure, they consult with the agency. The Appeals Panel reviews agency decisions to postpone disclosure of human rights records. If they agree to postpone, they determine alternative forms of disclosure, such as disclosing a summary or a substitute record. Upon completion of the review, they notify the agency of their determination. The Appeals Panel reviews agency decisions on disclosing human rights records, determining alternative forms of disclosure like summaries or substitute records. They notify the agency and publish their determination in the Federal Register within 14 days. The President is also informed with a written justification. The Panel publishes guidelines on its policy in the Federal Register. The Appeals Panel reviews agency decisions on disclosing human rights records and determines alternative forms of disclosure. The President has the authority to review the Panel's determination based on set standards and provide a written certification within 30 days, including reasons for the decision. The President must provide the Appeals Panel with a written certification stating the decision and reasons, including standards for postponing disclosure. The Panel will publish the President's certification and materials related to the postponement in the Federal Register. SEC. 8. The Information Security Policy Advisory Council will report to Congress on declassifying human rights records of other countries. SEC. 9. Ensures the Freedom of Information Act and judicial review rights are not limited. SEC. 10. Creation of positions. SEC. 10. Creation of 2 additional positions in the Appeals Panel for individuals with substantial human rights expertise appointed by the President with recommendations from human rights organizations.
